Overview.Summary: In the 2016 Bulgarian presidential election, Rumen Radev (2,8) emerged as the winner, with Tsetska Tsacheva (1,3,5,9) as his main opponent. The election was held in November (5,6,9) and had a record number of 23 candidates (9). Borisov resigned as Prime Minister after the election (8). The president is elected by absolute majority popular vote (5) in 2 rounds (5). The election was marked by a rapprochement between the Socialist Party and the Alternative for the Revival of Bulgaria (3).

Timeline.Text: Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov resigns after the victory of the pro-Russia candidate Rumen Radev in the presidential election.
Tsetska Tsacheva, the first woman president candidate in Bulgarian history, states the need for stability, national unity, and the rule of law.
The first round of the Bulgarian presidential election is held, with Rumen Radev and Tsetska Tsacheva advancing to the second round.
A record of 23 candidates are registered for the Bulgarian presidential election.

Overview.Summary: Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov announced his resignation following the defeat of his party's presidential candidate in the 2016 Bulgarian presidential election (1,2,4,5,7). His resignation was accepted by Bulgarian lawmakers (10). This election brought Socialist Party candidate Rumen Radev to power with 59% of the vote (3). Borisov's resignation sparked the possibility of new parliamentary elections (6,9).

Timeline.Text: Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov tenders his resignation after his party's candidate suffers a defeat in the presidential election.
Borisov's government officially resigns after the results of the presidential election on November 6.
Borisov refuses to form a new government and hands back the mandate, potentially leading to new parliamentary elections.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Bulgarian presidential election took place on November 6 and 13 (2,8). The first round was won by pro-Russian candidate Rumen Radev (3,5). The election was also accompanied by a referendum on changes to the electoral system and political party funding (2). Radev's victory resulted in the resignation of Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov (6). The election was closely watched due to similar claims of a rigged election in the US presidential election (7,10). Radev had previously served as the higher commander of the Bulgarian Air Force (1).

Timeline.Text: Presidential elections are held in Bulgaria alongside a referendum on changes to the electoral system and political party funding. The second round is scheduled for November 13.
Rumen Radev, a pro-Russian candidate, wins the first round of the Bulgarian presidential election.
Rumen Radev is officially declared the winner of the Bulgarian presidential election, resulting in the resignation of Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov.
In the midst of the Bulgarian presidential election, Donald Trump claims that the US election is rigged.
The Bulgaria for the Citizens Movement announces that they will leave the government if their candidate does not improve the party's results in the upcoming presidential election.

Overview.Summary: In the 2016 Bulgarian presidential election, Rumen Radev emerged as the winner with 59.4% of the vote (9). He was the candidate of the opposition Socialist party (1,2,4,5,6,8,10) and was also supported by the Alternative for Bulgarian Revival party (3). His victory was seen as a defeat for the ruling party and Prime Minister Boyko Borisov, who announced his resignation (2,5). Radev's victory was also supported by the second largest opposition party, DPS (4). He was a former air force commander (7) and ran as an independent candidate with the support of a group of citizens (9). His victory was seen as a win for the pro-Russian camp in Bulgaria (2,5).

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Bulgarian presidential election (9) saw Rumen Radev (2) win the first round as an independent candidate supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party and the Alternative for the Revival of Bulgaria (3). Boiko Borissov (6) resigned as Prime Minister after his party lost in the presidential runoff (5). Tsetska Tsasheva (1) was nominated as a candidate by the ruling party and had previously presided over the National Assembly of Bulgaria (1). Krassimir Karakachanov (8) of the United Patriots coalition took third place (8). The election was held on November 6 and saw a voter participation rate of 3,824,647 (7).

Timeline.Text: The first round of the Bulgarian presidential election takes place, with Rumen Radev and Tsetska Tsasheva as the two leading candidates.
Results from the first round of the presidential election show Rumen Radev as the leading candidate, followed by Tsetska Tsasheva and Krassimir Karakachanov.
Krassimir Karakachanov of the United Patriots coalition, which includes far-right parties, comes in third place in the first round of the presidential election.
Bulgarian Prime Minister Boiko Borissov resigns following the defeat of his party in the presidential runoff election.
Rumen Radev, a Russia-friendly candidate, is elected as the new president of Bulgaria.

Overview.Summary: On November 13, 2016, Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov announced his resignation after the Socialist candidate, Rumen Radev, won the presidential election (3, 6, 10). Radev, a former major general and commander of the Bulgarian Air Force, was supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party (2, 9). The election sparked a political crisis in Bulgaria (5, 7) and led to early parliamentary elections (3). The presidential election was held on November 6, 2016 (1, 8).

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Bulgarian presidential election (Event) was held on November 6 and 13, 2016 (5,7). Rumen Radev, the candidate of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, won the first round of the election with 25.7% of the vote (3). The election also included a referendum on changes to the electoral system (5). The first day of registration for candidates was September 19, 2016 (1). The voter turnout was 45% an hour before the polls closed (4). The current Prime Minister, Boiko Borisov, announced his resignation after the election results were announced (6).

Timeline.Text: The process of registering candidates for the Bulgarian presidential election begins.
Campaigns for the presidential election are underway.
The first round of the Bulgarian presidential election and a referendum on changes to the electoral system and political party funding are held.
With 95.2% of the ballots processed, the Central Election Commission reports that Rumen Radev leads the first round of the presidential election.
Rumen Radev is declared the winner of the first round of the Bulgarian presidential election.
The Sofia Globe staff reports on the provisional results of the presidential election.
The second round of the Bulgarian presidential election is held.
Bulgarian Prime Minister Boiko Borisov resigns after his party's candidate is defeated in the presidential election.
Acting President Shavkat Mirziyaev is declared the winner of the Uzbekistan presidential election.

Overview.Summary: In the 2016 Bulgarian presidential election, the results showed that Shavkat Mirziyaev won with 88.6% of the vote (1). The voter participation was 3,824,647 and there were no invalid votes (2). The election was held without any sectarian violence (3). A historic number of electors defected in this election (5). The opposition leader Nana Akufo-Addo won the national election in Ghana (7). According to exit polls, Rumen Radev, a pro-Russian candidate, won the first round of the Bulgarian presidential election (9).

Timeline.Text: Rumen Radev, a pro-Russian candidate, wins the first round of Bulgaria's presidential election.
Partial official results show Radev leading in the first round of the presidential election.
Exit polls show the percentage of votes by race in the presidential election.
Results for the popular vote in the presidential election are released.
Acting President Shavkat Mirziyaev wins the presidential election with 88.6 percent of the vote.
Mirziyaev's victory in the presidential election is officially confirmed by Uzbekistan's Central Election Commission.
Nana Akufo-Addo wins Ghana's national election, defeating incumbent President John Mahama.
The court upholds the December 2012 election results, clearing the way for Mahama to become president of Ghana.
A record number of electors defect in the presidential election, and most were expected to vote for the winner.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Bulgarian presidential election had a close race between the GERB party candidate, Tsetska Tsacheva, and independent candidate Rumen Radev (1, 2, 3, 4, 6). GERB party leader Boiko Borissov named Tsacheva as their candidate (4), and she was also endorsed by the junior ally in the coalition government (7). The election also saw a change in the electoral system, with Bulgarians voting in favor of a first-past-the-post system (9, 10).

Timeline.Text: Boiko Borissov's center-right GERB party expresses confidence in winning the presidential election, regardless of the candidate they choose.
Bulgarians will vote for a successor to President Rossen Plevneliev, with three additional referendum questions on the ballot.
Tsetska Tsacheva, the candidate of GERB, receives support from the Reformist Bloc, businessman Veselin Mareshki, and new ethnic Turk-dominated party DOST.
Rumen Radev, supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party, wins the presidential election with 59.4% of the vote.
After the election, GERB embraces changes to the electoral system, including a first-past-the-post system and compulsory voting.

Overview.Summary: In the 2016 Bulgarian presidential election, Rumen Radev, a former major general, won the election as an independent candidate supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party (1,2). He was chosen as the candidate for the government left, showing a rapprochement between the Socialist Party and the Alternative for the Revival of Bulgaria (ABV) (4). Radev's pro-Russia stance and call to end EU sanctions against Russia were seen as key factors in his victory (5,10). His opponent, Tsetska Tsacheva, was backed by the ruling GERB party (6,8). Radev's victory led to a political crisis in Bulgaria, with Prime Minister Boyko Borissov announcing his resignation (9).

Timeline.Text: Bulgarian politicians Rumen Radev and Tsetska Tsacheva participate in the first round of the presidential election.
Rumen Radev, supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party, wins the first round of the presidential election.
The second round of the presidential election begins, with Rumen Radev expected to win.
Rumen Radev, a newcomer to politics, wins the presidential election with support from the Bulgarian Socialist Party.

Overview.Summary: In the 2016 Bulgarian presidential election, Rumen Radev, supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party, won the presidency with 59.37% of the vote (3). This was a surprise victory over Tsetska Tsacheva, the candidate of the ruling GERB party (1, 3). The election saw a high voter turnout of 3,824,647 (4). The Movement for Rights and Freedoms party endorsed Plamen Oresharski as their candidate (6). Prime Minister Boyko Borisov resigned following the election results (8), but deferred the question of resignation until after the second round of elections (9). The race will continue in a runoff election on November 14 (10).

Timeline.Text: The first round of the Bulgarian presidential election is held, with Rumen Radev, supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party, receiving the most votes.
A runoff election is scheduled for the following weekend after no candidate gains an outright majority in the first round.
Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov announces his resignation after his party's candidate fails to win the presidential election.
Rumen Radev is officially declared the winner of the Bulgarian presidential election.

101.Title: MYTHS TRIUMPH OVER COMMON SENSE | VAGABOND
101.Snippet: Intricacies of Bulgarian Election Code jeopardise presidential election

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Bulgarian presidential election took place on November 6 and 13 (1,5,8,11,13,15,20). The first round saw Rumen Radev, a former major general, win with 25.7% of the vote (13). He was supported by the Bulgarian Socialist Party (3,4,6,12,17). The second round resulted in a victory for Radev with 88.6% of the vote (2). Radev's opponent was Tsetska Tsacheva, a member of the Citizens for European Development of Bulgaria party (8,9). The election was seen as a choice between East and West (14). The defeat of Tsacheva and her party led to the resignation of Prime Minister Boyko Borisov (3,4,15,19). The Democratic Party of Serbs (DPS) endorsed Radev in the second round (18). The election also included a referendum on changes to the electoral system (12).

Timeline.Text: The registration process for candidates for the November 6 2016 Bulgarian presidential election begins.
The Bulgarian presidential election takes place, with voter turnout estimated at 10% in the first three hours of voting.
Provisional results indicate that Rumen Radev has won the first round of the Bulgarian presidential election.
The Central Election Commission announces that Rumen Radev has won the first round of the Bulgarian presidential election with 25.7% of the vote.
Tsacheva casts her vote in the presidential runoff election, while Radev ultimately emerges as the winner.
The Bulgarian PM resigns after Radev's victory in the presidential election.
